title: How to Make Dried Apricot Jam

steps.headline: Place the dried apricots in a large bowl and cover with water.
steps.description: Leave to soak overnight.

steps.headline: Pour the apricots and water into a large saucepan.
steps.description: Cook on medium heat for 10 minutes, or until the apricots become soft.

steps.headline: Add sugar and stir until it is completely dissolved.
Reduce the heat and let the jam simmer.
steps.description: Stir occasionally during one hour, or until the jam gels when tested. Pour into sterilised hot jars. Let stand until cold and then seal.

steps.headline: Decorate if presenting as a gift by giving the jars a professional and elegant touch by using  a piece of fabric over the lid, tied down with a thin satin ribbon matching the fabric.
steps.description: Add a label so that the new owner can identify it, along with the date you made it.

steps.headline: Finished.
Prepare the dried apricots.
steps.description: Wash the apricots. Chop roughly.

steps.headline: Place the chopped apricots into a large bowl.
steps.description: Cover with warm water and let soak for a minimum of 8 hours.

steps.headline: Pour the soaked apricots and liquid into a preserving pan.
steps.description: Add the lemon juice and some zest.

steps.headline: Bring to the boil.
steps.description: Reduce to a simmer. Simmer for 20 to 30 minutes, taking care not to burn the apricots. Leave uncovered and stir frequently. When the apricots are soft, move to the next step.

steps.headline: Warm the sugar while the apricots are cooking.
steps.description: Once cooked, add the warmed sugar to the soft apricots. Bring to the boil again, stirring constantly. Cook until the sugar dissolves.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat to a simmer.
steps.description: Cook for another 30 minutes or until the jam reaches setting point. Keep an eye on the pot to prevent burning; you can stir occasionally if needed. If scum rises during cooking, skim off.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Add the almond slivers and stir through. Set aside to cool for 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Prepare the jam jars by sterilizing them.
steps.description: Stir the apricot jam, then transfer to the jars. Seal and label.

steps.headline: Store in a cool and dark place.
steps.description: The jam will be ready for eating after 2 weeks of sitting. This jam keeps for up to 6 months but should be refrigerated upon opening.

steps.headline: Wash the apricots.
steps.description: Cut into small pieces. You can skip cutting them if you like whole, chunky fruit jam.

steps.headline: Put the dried apricots into a medium bowl.
steps.description: Pour water to cover. Place an upside lid or plastic food wrap over the bowl and let soak overnight.

steps.headline: Drain the soaking water off but keep it.
Put the apricots into the preserving pan.
steps.description: Add 1 cup of the soaking water. Also tip in the lemon juice.

steps.headline: Add the sugar, vanilla and chopped chili pepper.
steps.description: Bring to the boil.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat.
steps.description: Simmer for 30 to 40 minutes, or until the jam reaches setting point. Stir occasionally to prevent burning.

steps.headline: Sterilize the jam jars during the cooking process.
steps.description: Ensure that they are dry before use.

steps.headline: Remove the jam from the heat.
steps.description: Pour into the jars. Seal and label.

steps.headline: Store in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Allow it to settle for a few days, as the spiciness will tone down while mixing with the apricots. This mixture will last for up to a month or so. Keep refrigerated.

Spicy dried apricot jam Wash the apricots.
Cut into small pieces.
You can skip cutting them if you like whole, chunky fruit jam.

Pour water to cover.
Place an upside lid or plastic food wrap over the bowl and let soak overnight.
Drain the soaking water off but keep it.
Put the apricots into the preserving pan.
Add 1 cup of the soaking water.
Also tip in the lemon juice.
Add the sugar, vanilla and chopped chili pepper.
Bring to the boil.
Reduce the heat.

This mixture will last for up to a month or so.
Keep refrigerated.
